captions.text: [CAR ENGINES]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JOHN HINDHAUGH: Spa
is a driver's
track, always has been.

What you've got to remember
about the Spa 24 is it isn't
[INAUDIBLE].

It's not the Nurburgring
24, either.

It's not Silverston's
24-hour race.
It has its own character.

Much of that comes from the
nature of the circuit, from

where it is in the world, in the
beautiful forested areas

of the Ardennes Forest, with the
weather problems that can
sweep in and sweep out.
It's a hard race.
It really is a hard race.

The cars look beaten
up after it.

There's always a
bit of weather.

So they come back, they've
been rain spattered.
They've been off the track.

It looks like they've
had a dog fight.

My goodness me, you get to the
end of the Spa 24 and you've
really achieved something.

LEO PARENTE: "Drive" also
likes to achieve.

So taking you places
we all want to see
is part of the gig.
And Spa 24 is a natural.

And there's a perfect reason I
was taking a McLaren to the
Spa 24 GT race.

And perfect got better
as my MP4-12C was
styled in McLaren orange.

So here's young and
old of English.
You!
You!
You!

The first miles, kilometers
behind the wheel, one can

already tell this McLaren is
capable of special things,

defying physics things,
but only to a point.

Getting across the English
Channel was not something an
MP4-12C can do unassisted.

Enter the Chunnel train,
literally.

The trip flashed by in a blink
thanks to the interest,

enthusiasm, and car stories that
percolated forth from the
other travelers.

With an Aston Martin, two
Porsche GT3, headed to the

Nurburgring for a lapping day,
and our Spa bound MP4-12C, we

definitely have the coolest rail
car on the Chunnel train.

So we've completed our
train tunnel tour.
And we're in France.

It's flatter, French cows, all
the cheese, and any cliche I
can think of.

So now we're just blasting
down their highway to get
closer to our destination.

We're going to find some side
roads to really liven this up.

Already we've blasted
one on-ramp.

And in track mode, this car
sticks like stripper glitter.

So the question is, will French
people respond to this

car the way the people
in the UK did.
We're on the highway.
I'm sure we'll find out.
Here come some passbys.

Belgium, however, provides
its own characteristic
stereotypes--

rain, and the most luscious
of backwood roads.

Max out the performance
buttons on this
McLaren, and let's go.

I can't believe I'm
driving a McLaren.
I grew up loving McLaren.

The PanAm in America, they used
to dominate, these orange
cars painted just like this.

Indy car-- the M16 and god knows
what else, used to be
Indy car winners.

F1, in 1968, Bruce McLaren
won at Spa.
It was the first McLaren win.

And McLaren won 112 Spa races
where we're headed, four in a
row by Ayrton Senna.
This is awesome.

And all those cars, they're
baked into this car.
[CAR ENGINE]

LEO PARENTE: I'd never drive
a Ferrari, for all the

reputation of all the
Ferrari owners.

This thing has the reputation
of being a pure race car.

And McLaren is all
about winning.
[CAR ENGINE]

LEO PARENTE: With "Drive,"
we've been to a
lot of tracks already.
We've been to the Nurburgring.

We've been to a lot of American
[INAUDIBLE] tracks.
We've been to the Daytona 24.

We've been to Mosport in Canada,
where they made a big

deal about the hyper high speed
turns two and four.

But I have a feeling that has
nothing in comparison to what
Spa is going to be all about.

Anytime you go to a track where
the corners have names

versus numbers, get ready for
real racing, and real race
driving tradition.

Spa, like every other major
European circuit, has changed

over the years for safety
reasons that are
hard to argue against--

unless you think they should
reopen the Roman Colosseum,
because that was real sports.

But as our friend John
said upfront,
the place has character.

ANTHONY BELTOISE: This race
track is very slippery, a lot
of humidity.
Only the line dry, one line.

So we have to stay on
the right line.

LEO PARENTE: Creative word
to describe Spa.
ADAM CHRISTODOULOU: Crazy.

ALVARO PARENTE: Spa is
always wet, dry,
all the time changing.
So challenging, really.

Challenging is the best
characteristic for this race.

JOHN HINDHAUGH: I've been there
for sports car and GTE

races, and walk around the
track, where you can see the
weather coming in a wave.

And one of the things about Spa
is being able to survive
those transitional conditions.

And the best drivers at Spa are
the drivers who are wary

but not intimidated of
those conditions.

LEO PARENTE: Tradition driven
by legacy, legend, and
accomplishment--
a point not lost on McLaren.

So they took advantage
of the moment.

Motorsport is always
about tradition,
and a little marketing.
But tradition is marketing.

And when you've raced and
won 24-hour races, like

[INAUDIBLE], and you're
competing at Spa, like

McLaren, you bring it all
together for a photo shoot.

The GT3 rules require pro
and amateur driving.

And that becomes the customer
racing part of this series,

and why the manufacturers have
really stepped up and
supported it.
These are not factory teams.

These are customer cars sold
to racers and racing teams.

A lot of the gentlemen drivers
are the ones that are really
funding this program.

Customer teams or factory
teams, racing is racing.

So let's take a look
at how this all
gets done at the track.

It starts with transporters,
one or two to move the
equipment on site.
Michelin spec tires--
they're inflated.

They're heated in the heat oven
because you can't use
tire warmers.

This is where all that's
managed to
bring it into the garage.
This is the operating area.

Two cars in the garage
here to do the work.

The crew resting between
pit stops and work.

Fuel rigs, scaffolding, and
lighting to help with the

fueling booms, to light
during the night.

GT3 is one spec here
at the Spa 24.

But the starting grid
tells you everything
about you GT3 racing.

We've got Audi versus McLaren,
Porsche, BMW
Z4, Mercedes Benz.

They're all grouped
at the front.

It's not just the rules
equalization.

These are teams that know what
it takes to go fast and win.

And they're all up here at
the front of the grid.

This race is going to be
what everyone expects--

67 cars, very professional
team in [INAUDIBLE].

The difference between
Nurburgring, it's more of an
experience.

Preparation, practice,
qualifying--

but it all comes down
to the race.

24 hours attacking the seven
kilometer, 4.4 mile track.

ANTHONY BELTOISE: Always
the challenge is
not to take the break.

So it's very difficult that it's
not completely flat that
the fantastic corner.

LEO PARENTE: From Raidillon to
Blanchimont the corners are

historic, and ever changing
through the Ardenne

climactics, the chase around the
clock, and the stout field
of diverse competitors.

DR. WOLFGANG ULRICH: You have
to be patient and careful,

especially in the first
10, 12 hours.

Because if you can't stay out of
trouble, there is no chance

to be at the end
of the podium.

It's always something that comes
that you did not expect.

ADAM CHRISTODOULOU: You've got
to stay out of trouble.

And the thing is
it's 24 hours.

So yo can't win the race
on the first lap.

So we just have to stay out of
trouble, try and stay out of

the pit lane, do our pit
stops, and just try and

continue as much as we can
throughout the race.

And obviously once you
get to hour 20, you
see where you are.

And if there's a position in
front or a few positions in

front that you can get,
then you try and push
to try and get them.

But it's about staying
out of trouble.

Anything can happen
in 24 hours.

LEO PARENTE: We're on the inside
of turn one, La Source,

the hairpin after
start finish.
And the crowd, very quiet.

I've never seen or felt or
heard that before, very

pensive, almost anticipating,
unlike Nurburgring, where
there was a buzz in the crowd.

This crowd, pretty good
enthusiasts are waiting,

waiting for the excitement of
this race, the passion.

You can feel a tension, but
a quiet, quiet tension.

The race cars are rolling
towards start finish.

The start of the Spa 24
is about to happen.
[CAR ENGINES]
[CAR ENGINES]

JOHN HINDHAUGH: The weather at
Spa, it always seems to me, is
only two things.

It's either beautifully sunny
or pouring with rain.

There never seems to be
anything in between.
[CAR ENGINES]

JOHN HINDHAUGH: And when I say
you hit a wall of water, I'm
not exaggerating.

LEO PARENTE: It's
raining at Spa.
We all knew that.

The teams get to put on
a spec Michelin tire.

We went full course yellow,
not because of the rain.

Because of the standing water
and rivers of rain that are
part of this track.

Why do fans still come to see
a race live, when there's so

much media available
to them these days?

To capture the moment
their way,
immediately, as it happens.

And to share the experience,
the friendship, the
passion, the food.

Speaking of which, when it comes
to racing, the cars may

run on fuel, the teams on cash,
but crews are powered by

the culinary drive of team
chefs and caterers.

You win over a crew
with great food.

A challenging racetrack, the
weather, a 24 hour time lapse.

The light shift into dusk
happens gradually.

But then, before you realize it,
the track becomes a black

space assaulted by a light
show called Spa 24.

And the racing takes on a look
only around the clock
endurance racing can deliver.

The Spa 24 holds true to all the
traditions of sports car

racing, and the belief
that having a
good time is timeless.

Enter the parties and the
techno beat concert.

Entertaining distractions, but
the never ending track action
remains the best show of all.
[CAR ENGINES]
[CAR ENGINES]

LEO PARENTE: The morning gave
light to the realities of what

transpired through
the evening.

Racing and otherwise, it was
hard to hide from the rigors
of what went on.

It was just time to deal with
it all, and press on.
[CAR ENGINES]
-Coffee?

LEO PARENTE: And then it came,
well played and planned or

just relieved to be here, the
24th hour ticked through.

Audi and their seemingly win at
will R8 Ultra took control

of this race, and finished
one, two.

All four Audi and BMW
at the front were
pro-driven race cars.

Pro-am went to the number 52
Ferrari from AF Corsa.

Alvaro Parente took the number
88 McLaren to P4
in Pro-am, P9 overall.

And got good intel for the
McLaren engineers to improve
the MP4-12C GT3.

We made the trip to Spa
for the same reason
so many fans do.

There's something intrinsically
right about race

cars built from the great
production sports cars.

GT race cars constructed to
perform at hyper elevated

levels of automotive capability,
but still

retaining the souls
of their essence.

GT race cars battling each
other, battling conditions

over the ultimate test of time,
24 hours of endurance,

may make TV producers and their
short attention span
mindset cringe.

But when the performance takes
place on the stage likes Spa,

with everything it offers to
the senses, the mind, the

imagination, and the memory
of tradition, we come.
And we will, every time.
[CAR ENGINES]
